title: Do Arabs and Iranians hate each other? - Quora

response.answer_text: This question keeps coming up on my feed, but only using different words: “Do Iranians hate Arabs?”“Why do Iranians hate Arabs?”“Do Arabs hate Iranians?”“Why do Arabs hate Iranians?”These questions need to stop, I as Iranian (well American with Iranian background) do not hate Arabs, I have had many Arab friends living in America. One of my best friends in North Caroline named Waleed Abu-Salah was an Arab. Many Quorans I like such as Ahmad Kadan (أحمد گعدان), Ahmad El-Sheikh (أحمد الشيخ), Ahmed Rabee' (أَحْمَدْ رَبِيع), Ahmed Abdelhaq Zaydan, Sana Khoury, Salwa Halabia, Ziaddinè Chahoudi and others that I have probably forgotten are Arabs. What about Gulf Arabs? I assume this question has to due to Proxy War between Iran and Saudi Arabia. Well for me personally, the war plays a very little impact on my life. Second, despite the conflict, I doubt the conflict effects the opinions of rational folks in both countries. I like Abdulaziz Al Meajel, he’s a Gulf Arab from Kuwait, I think I initially got off to a bad start with him, but were not cool with one another. And as for citizens of Saudi Arabia, well there are things about Saudi Arabia that I find very reprehensible, but I have nothing against any ordinary citizen of the Kingdom. They are just people trying live their lives, like Iranians. I don’t get why many Westerns seem to think that Arabs and Iranians are each other’s natural enemies. There are certainly people of both sides, such as Sunni extremist, Arab Nazis, Pseudo-Persian Nationalists, etc, who proudly boast their hatred of the other group on social media. But they are fringe minority among both ethnic groups, just as White Nationalists are among White Americans and Afro-Centrists among Black Americans. In case I get the “Iranians hate Arabs because of the 7th Century Arab Invasion” comment from Orientalists, I will let you know that three centuries before the Arab Conquest of Persia, that Persians also victimized Arabs. In 325 AD, the Sassassind Shah Shapur II launched a campaign in Eastern Arabia that resulted into ethnic cleansing of several Arab tribes, primary the Iyad, Taghlib, Banu Bakr, Banu Abdul Qays, Banu Tamim, and Banu Hanzalah. And after the campaign Shapur II wanted to Arab tribes further West, so he built a wall and made the Arabs pay for it. Note: I am kidding about paying for the wall part Shapur II's Arab campaign - Wikipedia Sasanian defense lines - Wikipedia So as you now know, Iranians are not the innocent victim bystander in antiquity. Most Iranians don’t want to be painted by Orientalists as the civilized Persians who were brutality conquered by primitive savage camel jockeys. Iran has been invaded by many empires. Alexander the Great conquered Persia and massacred the entire population of Persepolis, yet most Iranians have no ill will against modern Greek people. Genghis Khan conquered Persia and massacred around 75–90% of Persia’s population, yet most Iranians have to ill will against modern Mongolian people. The Brits and the Russians during WWI caused a famine that killed around 8–10 Million Iranians, yet most Iranians have no ill will against either British or Russian people. Solh صلح and Salaam سلام to everyone.

There are some good answers here. I share my perspective. The hatred towards Arabs from Iranians, is three fold: LanguageReligionHistory1. Language We Iranians are really proud of our language. Persian is among the top ten old languages of the world. And relative to Latin or German languages, we changed very little. The invasion of Arabs in 7th century, resulted in a very dramatic change in Persian. We adopted Arabic alphabet, we adopted many Arabic words and even Parsi, (which is also the name of our language) changed to Farsi, because Arabs couldn't pronounce P. The changes were so dramatic that almost killed Persian. But some poets, writers, and kings, intervened. Today, as an Islamic country, studying Arabic, is mandatory in school. And the method of learning, is almost 100 years out of date. So it is among one of the most hated classes between students.  2. Religion As Arabs invaded Iran, they injected their religion as well. Islam. It was not much of a problem (though in that time many were killed, but we can count that as a result of war and invasion.) But when Safavid got the power in Iran, The change to Shiite Islam became mandatory. As Safavid wanted to unite people against Turkey, in which time, there was a war in between. That passed and then came the Iranian revolution in which resulted in a dictatorship with the doctarian of Islam. And many were killed by the name of Islam. They were not killed because of Islam though. But when you mention Islam as your motif when you mass-murder, It gets to people. And Islam generally is linked to Arabs. So, there goes the hatred from that perspective. 3. History Iran as an old civilization had many kings coming and going. But the most glorious ones were ones that were ended by invasion of Arabs. And at that time, the Great Persia, started to shrink down and loose its power and humanism.   And to add to other points, there is the problem that comes from revolutions, which cause extremism, which cause bigotry and with that comes racism.   But in General I can say that, in popular culture, there is not much hatred towards Arabs, as there is towards mandatory Islam and mandatory Arabic. We can say, Islam, Arabic and Arabs are not popular in youth of current Iran. But hatred is not much of the case as the "mandatory" part are.

Everybody is listing the reasons for the bitter emotions amongst Arabs and Persians, but I’m going to tell you about my very personal experience. So let’s start with my childhood. At that age, I had no idea of human diversity and consequently had no idea of the existence of Arab or Persian ethnicities. I was born right after the Iran-Iraq war. All that I can remember was the memorial of martyrs on the state TV. Along with these programs, there were some other programs about the Palestine-Israel conflict; so I just mixed it up and thought that Palestine is part of Iran and Israel is another name of Iraq :) Apart from that, I used to hear some of our relatives were living and working in Kuwait and Dubai. Those who were working in Kuwait were called Kuwaiti and it was relatively synonym of wealthy because they could earn so much money and send it back home. Again I thought of Kuwait and Dubai as some cities in Iran! So no knowledge of Arabs yet. Then when did I get to know there are some people, different from us, called Arabs? Well, it all started with football. The first matches I can recall are 2002 world cup qualifications. Saudi Arabia and Bahrain were Arab teams in our group. In Tehran, IRN beat SA and since the commentator was overjoyed I found out that it wasn’t an ordinary match. In Riyadh, it was a draw, but at the moments the SA was the victorious team, from what commentator said, I learnt it’s so shameful to lose against SA! After that, the most important match was IRN-BHRN, even with a draw Iran could get qualified for the world cup. But to everybody’s surprise, IRN lost the match and Bahraini players and some of their fans waved SA’s flag (that win didn’t benefit Bahrain, it just paved the way for SA to get qualified for the world cup). If it was up to me, I wouldn’t have got offended, but from what the commentator and other mature football fans said I learnt it was so offensive and I should be outraged. Before this, I used to think the only enemies that we had were the USA and Israel, and all the Muslim countries are on our side. But after these matches, I learnt that being Muslim is not the thing that unites us, but the race and language are of much more importance. As time elapsed and I grew up, from what I read in history books and heard on the news, I learnt it was Arabs who invaded us in Iran-Iraq war (not Israel) and it wasn’t the first time they’d invaded. Some said a Saudi Mufti has a fatwa that you’d be rewarded if you kill or rape a Shia. They said another Mufti had said I wish for a day when Persians are beggars in our streets. I read a book named "two centuries of silence" in which Arab conquest of Persia was narrated in a dark theme (I think I’d better point it out that, despite the claims about Iranian government being anti-Arab, it was completely the opposite. In our textbooks, we read that Sassanid kings were incompetents, so when the Persians were offered the new faith, they accepted it with open arms. Besides that, I frequently heard from our clerics that they wish for the unity of the Muslim world). So despite all I’d learnt about our tumultuous history of our nation with Arabs, I expected Arabs and all the Muslim countries to be on our side against our non-Muslim enemies. But it wasn’t realistic and I learnt it when the news of wiki leaks came out and there was some evidence of SA’s conspiracy against Iran. I would laugh at my feelings at that time. I felt like I had been betrayed and I had the same feeling when SA raised its oil production to foil the effect of Iran’s sanctions (I had no idea of a political and economic rivalry between the two). And I found out our enemies even have military bases in our neighbouring countries. The Arab Spring and its aftermath made these negative attitudes even stronger. Not that I support Iran’s policies in the Arab countries. I just find it unfair to only blame Iran for its so-called ambitions. Every Arab citizen I’ve come across has had a very biased opinion on this matter. While Persians admit their government destructive role in the region, Arabs consider themselves purely as innocent. To be honest our complaints about our government’s interference in other countries is for our own sake. There’s a popular slogan in Iranian’s demonstrations which says "no to Gaza, no to Lebanon, I will sacrifice my life for Iran". There are some other disputable matters amongst Arabs and Persians, including the UAE claims about our Islands and the name of the Persian Gulf. But believe me, as far as I know, there’s no religious basis to these sentiments. I read in many responses that the root of this bitterness is Shia-Sunni conflicts, but I guarantee that it’s not. Many Iranians are far less religious than what people assume. These non-religious Persians don’t care about religion (be it Shia, Sunni or even atheist), and about religious ones you can’t say they hate Arabs at all, they have some complaints about some Arab countries’ policies but you never hear them saying we hate Arabs. So in conclusion, if you ask me: why do you have bitter feelings against Arabs? I would say: because I found out they dislike us. But does it mean I would disrespect them or mistreat them when I meet? No, not at all. A year ago my Arab friend (Iranian Arab) had a guest from Iraq. he wasn’t pro-Iran (even maybe anti-Iran), he just came over to see my friend. Knowing that, we all were more than hospitable toward him. We showed him around and even got angry when someone overcharged him. Who knows?! maybe all this bitterness is restricted to the internet :D

As you can see, the Muslims conquered a lot of regions during the 7th and 8th century, including Persia. During this time, Arabic became widespread in the Middle East, North Africa, and the Iberian Peninsula. This was necessary, because the Umayyad empire was Islamic, and its system was based on the caliphate. It’s important to note that nationalism is absolutely forbidden in Islam, and that the spread of Arabic in the Umayyad empire had nothing to do with nationalism. The prophet Muhammad - peace and blessings be upon him - was an Arabian, and to be more precise, he was a descendant of the prophet Ismael, and Ismael is the son of the prophet Abraham - peace be upon them. The Jews also descend from the prophet Abraham, albeit not from his son Ismael, but from his other son Isaaq - peace be upon him. This is the reason why both Arabs and Jews are known as Semitic people. Since the prophet Muhammad was Arabian, and the message, which he conveyed to the people in the Arabian Peninsula was in Arabic, it’s pretty obvious as to why the Muslims were learning Arabic during that time. According to Islamic scholars, it was important that Arabic was taught to every Muslim - both men and women - so that they could understand the Qur’an and the narrations about the prophet Muhammad - peace be upon him. A lot of Persians became Muslim, and the non-Muslim Persians were also tolerated in the Umayyad empire. Keep also in mind that Persians were mostly Sunnis before the Persian conversion to Shi’ism began in the 16th century, which would have dramatic consequences.  This man is known as ‘Shah Ismail’, he was the first Safavid ruler of Persia during the 16th century. He wanted to convert all the Sunni Persians to Shi’ism, and what he did was unprecedented, because he forced all the Persians to become Shi’ites, and whoever refused to convert, would be executed instantaneously. This kind of oppression was a nightmare to the Sunnis, and I honestly feel very sad for all those Sunnis who lived in Persia during that time. As time past, the Persians and Arabs no longer had any connection with each other. Arabs were mostly against Shi’ism due to the fact that Shi’ism contains a lot of polytheistic ideas, which are considered to be anti-Islamic. The fourth caliph Ali - may Allaah be pleased with him - didn’t invite people to get worshiped, but despite this, the Shi’ites insisted on worshiping him. Another act of disbelief, which the Shi’ites also did, was that they cursed the spouse of the prophet Muhammad, and they also cursed the first 3 caliphs. There are many more acts of disbelief that are very common among Shi’ites, but in spite of this, they still claim to be Muslim. It baffles me when I hear them call themselves Muslim, because they’ve actually rejected the tenets of Islam. The hatred that you asked about has nothing to do with race, I can assure you that. It’s about the clash between the Sunnis and the Shi’ites. Honestly, if the Shi’ites nowadays would become Sunnis, then the tension would go away, no doubt about it. May Allaah guide the Shi’ites to the straight path, amin. Greetings, Faysel

I find it sad that both parties are not focussing on what they have in common instead. However, I wish during that time everybody let go of passive feelings and wish each other safety and health.

There are four different ways to answer this question. Are there Arabs who hate Iranians? Yes there are. I remember when Muhammed Morsi made his visit to Iran, there were rumours about Shia Islam spreading to Egypt. Of course this is an absurd and baseless rumour, but it’s an example based on my personal experience. You’ve also got Arabs who hate Iranians on the basis of the “Ahwazi independence movement”. Are there Arabs who like Iranians? Yes there are. Shiites in Iraq view Iranian Shiites as brothers separated by borders. There are a lot more Arabs who view Iranians as friends on the basis of religion. And of course there are Arabs who sympathize with Iranians and wish to see an end to the Islamic Republic. I personally like Iran (not the government) and its people. Are there Iranians who hate Arabs? Yes there are. I’ve seen a lot of Iranians who hate Arabs on Quora making absurd and baseless accusations. One Quoran in particular accused Arabs of “stealing Iranian music because they’re jealous.” Others have decided to blame Arabs for the overthrowing of the Shah despite there being no evidence of Arab involvement in 1979. Are there Iranians who like Arabs? Yes there are. Again, there are Iranians who like Arabs on a religious basis, viewing Shiite Arabs as allies. Then you’ve got the Iranian government, which likes Arabs so much that they’re spending more money on militias in the Middle-East than on their own citizens — of course I’m exaggerating, they’re not really doing it out of love for the Arabs.  I answered this question in four different ways just to prove to you that there is no overall consensus. There are Indians and Pakistanis who hate each other and others who like each other. There are Mexicans and Americans who hate each other and others who like each other. The list goes on, but hopefully you understand my point.
